title: How to Make a Stuffed Ninja

steps.headline: Lay out black fabric and fold in two.
steps.description: Make sure the right sides are touching each other.

steps.headline: With chalk (or other writing utensil visible on the particular kind of black fabric you have) trace out a human shape.
steps.description: It doesn't need to be too perfect, and it looks cuter if it isn't. Just make sure it looks sort of like a person, at the very least, with arms and legs. The easiest shape is a rectangle with tiny stubby arms and legs.

steps.headline: Cut out your shape, making sure to leave seam allowances.
With the two pieces of fabric lined up on top of each other, wrong sides out, start sewing all around, with a sewing machine or by hand.
steps.description: Leave a small opening somewhere, to turn it right side out. (1 inch/2.5 cm is good)

steps.headline: Turn it right side out and insert the stuffing.
steps.description: With the back of a pencil or a similar object, push the stuffing in so that your ninja doesn't turn out floppy. Sew the opening closed using blind stitch.

steps.headline: Now cut out an oval shape in the accent colour.
steps.description: Skin tones (such as a light pink, white, yellowish, tan or brown shades) work best to make a more life-like ninja but you can use any colour for this.

steps.headline: Sew the oval on the place where you want the ninja face to go.
steps.description: Use white thread so that the stitches will be less noticeable. You'll most likely want to match the face color of the ninja or use black thread.

steps.headline: Embroider or sew in the eyes.
steps.description: The possibilities are endless: use beads, buttons or embroider filled circles or even crosses if you'd rather have a knocked-out/fainted ninja. Use any colour you like or even different sized eyes for that home-made look.

steps.headline: Add any details you may like such as embroidering his/her name on the back, adding lashes or a pink (or red or any other coloured) bow to a female ninja, or embroidering a little mouth or sew in a small pink tongue poking out.

text: Lay out black fabric and fold in two. Make sure the right sides are touching each other. With chalk (or other writing utensil visible on the particular kind of black fabric you have) trace out a human shape. It doesn't need to be too perfect, and it looks cuter if it isn't. Just make sure it looks sort of like a person, at the very least, with arms and legs. The easiest shape is a rectangle with tiny stubby arms and legs. Cut out your shape, making sure to leave seam allowances.  With the two pieces of fabric lined up on top of each other, wrong sides out, start sewing all around, with a sewing machine or by hand. Leave a small opening somewhere, to turn it right side out. (1 inch/2.5 cm is good) Turn it right side out and insert the stuffing. With the back of a pencil or a similar object, push the stuffing in so that your ninja doesn't turn out floppy. Sew the opening closed using blind stitch. Now cut out an oval shape in the accent colour. Skin tones (such as a light pink, white, yellowish, tan or brown shades) work best to make a more life-like ninja but you can use any colour for this. Sew the oval on the place where you want the ninja face to go. Use white thread so that the stitches will be less noticeable. You'll most likely want to match the face color of the ninja or use black thread. Embroider or sew in the eyes. The possibilities are endless: use beads, buttons or embroider filled circles or even crosses if you'd rather have a knocked-out/fainted ninja. Use any colour you like or even different sized eyes for that home-made look. Add any details you may like such as embroidering his/her name on the back, adding lashes or a pink (or red or any other coloured) bow to a female ninja, or embroidering a little mouth or sew in a small pink tongue poking out.
